abstract: European inflation accelerated in October more than economists forecast, while confidence in the economy declined, underlining the European Central Bank’s quandary over whether to raise interest rates. The inflation rate in the 13-nation euro area rose to a two-year high of 2.6 percent, from 2.1 percent in September, the European Union’s statistics office in Luxembourg said. That was above the 2.3 percent expected by economists. An index of executive and consumer sentiment fell to a 19-month low of 105.9 in October, according to a separate report.

abstract: Penn West Energy Trust, a Canadian energy trust, agreed to acquire Canetic Resources Trust for about 3.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.8 billion) to cushion the impact of a new tax. The combined trust would have tax pools, or accrued credits used to reduce tax payments, valued at about 5.5 billion Canadian dollars at the end of 2007, according to the statement. Canetic’s unit holders would receive 0.515 of a Penn West unit and a distribution of 9 cents a Canetic unit before the closing, according to the companies. That values the offer at 15.84 Canadian dollars for each Canetic unit, 7.1 percent above the closing price on Tuesday. Both companies are based in Calgary.

abstract: Advice from a resume expert on how to make yours a recruiter’s dream.
snippet: Advice from a resume expert on how to make yours a recruiter’s dream.
lead_paragraph: I have invited Susan Strayer to do a guest post on why the résumé above is a recruiter’s dream. As the corporate director of talent management for the Ritz-Carlton Hotel company and private career coach, Ms. Strayer has reviewed thousands of résumés. She is also the author of The Right Job, Right Now, which was published earlier this year. But before we get started, I have a caveat. I think we are getting to the point where many people (especially entrepreneurial types) won’t be using traditional résumés. Instead, they will rely on narrative bios, personal Web sites, or preformatted résumés posted on social networking sites like LinkedIn. But until that time, it’s wise to have a traditional résumé handy.

headline.main: How to Spiff Up Your Résumé

lead_paragraph: WITHOUT quite having a clear plan, Gregg Rottler began contemplating his Web empire last year on his desktop computer at his home near Tampa, Fla. As many bloggers have done, Mr. Rottler, a state environmental code officer, followed an impulse to share stories about annoyances. He and his wife, Karen, an elementary school teacher, often eat out, and he realized that people liked to talk about restaurant experiences gone wrong.

abstract: THE WORST YEAR Domestic airline performance through September of this year ranked as the worst for any comparable period in at least 12 years, the Transportation Department’s Bureau of Transportation Statistics reported yesterday. Through September, 73.18 percent of flights arrived on time this year, compared with 76.14 percent in the same period last year and the 12-year high, 82.82 percent in 2003. The worst 3 of the top 32 major airports through September of this year were all in the New York area: Newark Liberty (59.60 percent on time) LaGuardia (59.85 percent) and Kennedy (60.86 percent). The best three were Salt Lake City (80.31 percent), and Oakland (80.22 percent) and San Diego (78.95 percent) in California.

abstract: Getinge, the world’s largest maker of surgical workstations, agreed to buy two Boston Scientific Corporation units for $750 million to expand its tools for heart operations. Getinge, based in Stockholm, said it was cutting expenses and making purchases to become more profitable. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said it was selling the units to reduce debt and focus on businesses with more growth potential.

Buying Nufarm gives China National entry to the $36 billion global market for herbicides and pesticides as a worldwide agricultural boom spurs acquisitions.

abstract: CBS’s five-year-old series “NCIS” earned its largest audience ever on Tuesday, surpassing even the night’s usual leaders including ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” and Fox’s “House.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the Navy-themed crime drama delivered 18.3 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour, just more than the 18.1 million who tuned in at 9 p.m. for “House.”
lead_paragraph: CBS’s five-year-old series “NCIS” earned its largest audience ever on Tuesday, surpassing even the night’s usual leaders including ABC’s “Dancing With the Stars” and Fox’s “House.” According to Nielsen’s estimates, the Navy-themed crime drama delivered 18.3 million viewers in the 8 p.m. hour, just more than the 18.1 million who tuned in at 9 p.m. for “House.”

abstract: A new animated Web series mocks the presidential candidates and hopes to make it to regular television
snippet: A new animated Web series mocks the presidential candidates and hopes to make it to regular television
lead_paragraph: Barack Obama is Luke Skywalker, Hillary Clinton is Princess Leia, Rudolph Giuliani is Han Solo and Mitt Romney looks like the PackBot from iRobot, but is probably R2D2. I don’t know what it all means, but Israeli humor site AniBoom’s new animated series, Race for the White House, is worth a look – particularly if you are starved for laughs during the ongoing Hollywood writer’s strike.

abstract: If you’re a Gmail user, you can now set up your account to use Internet Message Access Protocol with your favorite e-mail program.
snippet: If you’re a Gmail user, you can now set up your account to use Internet Message Access Protocol with your favorite e-mail program.
lead_paragraph: If you’re a Gmail user, you can now set up your account to use Internet Message Access Protocol (IMAP) with your favorite e-mail program. Unlike the older POP mail system, which typically confines message downloads to the computer or the device you are working on, IMAP is server-based so your mailbox has all the current messages no matter where you use it — on a computer, Web browser or mobile device. Using IMAP with Gmail is free, and instructions on setting it up with different mail programs are at preview.tinyurl.com/yofbl9.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Viewing Gmail From Anywhere

abstract: German industrial output unexpectedly increased in September, led by the construction and energy sectors.
snippet: German industrial output unexpectedly increased in September, led by the construction and energy sectors.
lead_paragraph: German industrial output unexpectedly increased in September, led by the construction and energy sectors. Production rose a seasonally adjusted 0.3 percent from August, when it advanced 1.9 percent, the Economy and Technology Ministry said. Economists expected a 0.5 percent decline. Output rose 6 percent from the period a year earlier, when adjusted for the number of working days. Construction rose 0.7 percent in September from a month earlier and energy output gained 1 percent, the report said. Production of consumer durables was down 4.4 percent.

headline.main: Germany: Industrial Output Rises
headline.print_headline: Germany: Industrial Output Rises

lead_paragraph: I get it now: Barry Diller wants IAC/InterActiveCorp to be the Microsoft of the Internet. I’m not saying that he seeks world domination and monopoly power over a billion computers. IAC’s starship of a headquarters on the Hudson River is certainly playing to type there.

abstract: An article on Sept. 23 about the performance of Hertz, the rental car company, since its buyout by private equity firms in 2005 referred imprecisely to some of its past practices. At times, Hertz indeed used outside printers and other outsourcing for some work and used financial yardsticks like Ebitda and cash flow; those practices did not start after the buyout, though they have been expanded broadly. And before 2000, Hertz’s chief executive reported directly to senior managers such as the chief financial officer and vice chairman of Ford, a previous owner of Hertz; the chief executive did not report to lower-level managers. A letter dated Oct. 2 from Frank A. Olson, chief executive of Hertz from 1977 to 1999, clarifying certain past practices, was misdirected within The Times. This correction was further delayed for research.

abstract: Isuzu Motors, Japan’s biggest maker of light trucks, had a 26 percent drop in second-quarter operating profit after rising overseas vehicle sales failed to make up for a slump in domestic demand. Operating profit, or sales minus the cost of goods sold and selling, general and administrative expenses, fell to 25 billion yen ($227 million) in the three months that ended Sept. 30, from 33.7 billion yen a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent, to 472.4 billion yen.

abstract: WestLB, the German state-owned bank based in Düsseldorf, said it would report a full-year loss of more than 100 million euros ($145 million) because of “persistently difficult market developments.” The lender will post a pretax “low three-digit million euro loss,” in contrast to an original forecast of a profit, according to a statement. The company, which is scheduled to publish nine-month earnings on Dec. 6, blamed “the substantial price losses of structured securities in the past weeks.”.

abstract: BUSINESS-CLASS SALES The trans-Atlantic business-class fare war for holiday travel that Continental started recently is escalating as American, Lufthansa and eight other carriers have joined in. Round-trip business-class fares on trans-Atlantic routes, which can cost $10,000 at regular walk-up prices, are being offered at $1,200 and less by some carriers for limited periods over the Thanksgiving and Christmas holidays. Matthew Bennett, publisher of the online premium air travel newsletter Flightbliss.com, suggests that the discounts are a good way for elite-status frequent fliers to take holiday trips in comfort while padding their year-end totals of miles needed to requalify for elite status next year. Business-class fares, he points out, often yield extra qualifying mileage credit.

lead_paragraph: When I decided to become a lawyer 20 years ago, it was a decision laden with shoulds, mostly from my father, who was projecting his wishes onto me. (His “Marci should be a lawyer” became “I should please my father and become a lawyer.”) If I had listened better to my own vision for a career, I might have found a career that fit me better the first time around.

headline.main: What ‘Should’ You Do in Your Career?

While the cause of its death is generally seen as Amaranth’s ill-fated energy trades, Amaranth is proposing a controversial new theory. The defunct fund, which once oversaw more than $9 billion, argues that improper meddling by J.P. Morgan Chase was the real reason that it didn’t pull through the crisis.

lead_paragraph: More than 13 minutes into ABC’s live broadcast of the American Music Awards last night, after musical numbers by Fergie, will.i.am and Nicole Scherzinger, the host finally made his appearance and opened with the lines: “I’m Jimmy Kimmel and this is my fourth time hosting the show and, uh, my first time hosting it drunk. So I’m very excited to be here.” Presumably it was an ad-lib: Mr. Kimmel went on to explain that as a member of the Writers Guild he was on strike — “in my heart,” at least — and couldn’t write any jokes.

abstract: The overall number of Americans traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday season will rise by a slight 1.5 percent this year.
snippet: The overall number of Americans traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday season will rise by a slight 1.5 percent this year.
lead_paragraph: THANKSGIVING TRAVEL With gasoline prices averaging well over $3 a gallon nationally, the overall number of Americans traveling during the Thanksgiving holiday season will rise by a slight 1.5 percent this year, the automobile and travel association AAA says. “A year ago, prices were in the range of $2.20 a gallon, so this year travelers are really feeling the pinch,” Robert L. Darbelnet, the group’s president, said in a statement. (AAA has a state-by-state gasoline cost and fuel-mileage calculator at www.fuelcostcalculator.com.) While other surveys show that rates at luxury and big city hotels are up, there is some good news. Rates at midlevel hotels with AAA Three-Diamond ratings are down 3 percent from last year. THE BRITISH ARE NOT COMING Although the weak dollar compared with the pound makes travel in the United States a bargain for Britons, British leisure and business travel to the United States is down by 11 percent since 2000, says the Discover America Partnership, a travel industry group. It cited Commerce Department figures. Without the lure of the exchange rate, “the persistent decline in British travelers would be even worse,” the group says. It blames time-consuming and sometimes rude Customs and Immigration procedures at airports and a poor image of the United States abroad for an overall 17 percent decline in overseas travel to the United States since late 2001.

lead_paragraph: There’s been a lot of talk about personal branding lately. A few weeks ago, I heard Catherine Kaputa, author of U R a Brand, speak at a conference. She told a story about a book with a great idea that achieved only modest sales. But then it was repackaged with some attention paid to branding and went on to captivate dieters around the country. The book’s original title was The Moderate Carbohydrate Diet. The book’s modified title? The South Beach Diet. Ms. Kaputa’s book is about how to apply this kind of thinking to ourselves.

headline.main: Done Anything for Your Brand Lately?

abstract: German producer-price inflation, an early indicator of price pressures in the economy, accelerated more than economists expected in October after the price of oil rose to a record and the cost of food surged.

lead_paragraph: German producer-price inflation, an early indicator of price pressures in the economy, accelerated more than economists expected in October after the price of oil rose to a record and the cost of food surged. Prices for goods ranging from newsprint to plastics climbed 1.7 percent from a year earlier after rising 1.5 percent in September, the Federal Statistics Office said. Economists had expected a 1.6 percent gain. “Price pressures are now definitely building up,” said Rainer Guntermann, an economist at Dresdner Kleinwort in Frankfurt.

abstract: To optimists, huge investments by major developers provide proof that New Rochelle, New York’s renaissance has begun. Yet there remain few signs of renewed economic vitality downtown.

abstract: Want to read long files on your iPod or iPod Nano, but can’t get around the iPod’s 4-kilobyte size limit on text documents?
snippet: Want to read long files on your iPod or iPod Nano, but can’t get around the iPod’s 4-kilobyte size limit on text documents?
lead_paragraph: Want to read long files on your iPod or iPod Nano, but can’t get around the iPod’s 4-kilobyte size limit on text documents? Upload that hefty text or e-book file to the iPod eBook Creator site (snipurl.com/1tpx6) and get it back in a batch of linked 4K chunks. Copy those files into your iPod’s Notes folder and you’ve got a pocket book for the morning commute. You can find plenty of free e-book text files to download at Project Gutenberg (www.gutenberg.us).

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Reading Long Files on Your iPod

abstract: DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the biggest initial public stock offering ever in the Middle East.
snippet: DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the biggest initial public stock offering ever in the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: DP World, the Dubai-owned port operator with terminals from Britain to China, raised $4.96 billion in the biggest initial public stock offering ever in the Middle East. The company sold shares for $1.30 each, the top of an indicated range, after buyers put in orders for 15 times the number of shares offered, the company said. The stock sale gives the company a market value of $21.6 billion. The offering surpassed the initial stock offering of the Saudi Telecom Company, which raised $4.1 billion in 2003. “The fact the I.P.O. has been so heavily oversubscribed reflects the market’s confidence. DP World will have a solid base of international investors,” Sultan Ahmed Bin Sulayem, DP World’s chairman, said in a statement.

headline.main: Dubai: Port Operator Raises $5 Billion
headline.print_headline: Dubai: Port Operator Raises $5 Billion

abstract: Airbus won a $2.65 billion order from OceanAir, a Brazilian carrier that plans to add domestic and international flights.
snippet: Airbus won a $2.65 billion order from OceanAir, a Brazilian carrier that plans to add domestic and international flights.
lead_paragraph: Airbus won a $2.65 billion order from OceanAir, a Brazilian carrier that plans to add domestic and international flights. OceanAir agreed to buy seven A330-200 widebody planes, 14 A319s and seven A320s, Airbus said. OceanAir also took options for 13 more aircraft worth $900 million. The estimates are based on list prices and do not reflect discounts applied to large orders. The new aircraft will allow closely held OceanAir to better compete with TAM and Gol Linhas Aéreas Inteligentes, which have a combined 91 percent of domestic air travel in Brazil. “We want to woo those future customers,” OceanAir’s owner, German Efromovich, above, said. The carrier will change its name to Avianca next year, matching its brand in Colombia. The airline wants to increase its Brazilian market share to as much as 15 percent by 2010, from 2.2 percent now, Mr. Efromovich said.

lead_paragraph: The British government laid out a multibillion-dollar proposal to allow construction of a third runway and a sixth passenger terminal at London’s chronically congested Heathrow Airport, stoking the ire of environmentalists who fear that increases in air traffic are accelerating global climate change. Ruth Kelly, the transport secretary, said the expansion plan would pave the way for a near doubling of the number of passengers using the airport, Europe’s busiest, to 120 million a year by 2020. The British Civil Aviation Authority has estimated that the project could cost as much as £9 billion ($18.5 billion).

lead_paragraph: Renault of France will start building cars in South Africa from 2009 to expand its share of sales in rapidly growing emerging markets. The company will assemble entry-level Sandero cars at a plant owned by its affiliate, Nissan Motor, north of Pretoria, Patrick Pelata, Renault’s vice president of Asia-Africa projects, told reporters in Johannesburg. Renault may export the car to other parts of Africa and to Europe. South Africa produced 590,000 vehicles last year, giving it a share of world production of just under 1 percent. The government encourages exports by giving carmakers discounts on imported vehicles and components. Renault’s chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, says he intends to increase the company’s total sales by 39 percent, to 3.33 million vehicles, in the next three years.

abstract: "I just finished reading your article in today's paper. I am a physician and occasionally debate the topic of mistakes, errors, and negligence with legal acquaintances. The plaintiff attorneys equate error with negligence (and therefore payment) without exception. I counter that while certainly not desired, and as you point out when someone's life is in your hands we strive to "avoid mistakes as much as possible", perfection is not humanly possible. Negligence is, or should be, harmful action beyond the range of customary or expected outcome. In my opinion, this is not the same as error free which is an unattainable standard. Yet, try and convince a lay jury in retrospective analysis a decision, diagnosis, judgment was "wrong" but not negligent.
lead_paragraph: "I just finished reading your article in today's paper. I am a physician and occasionally debate the topic of mistakes, errors, and negligence with legal acquaintances. The plaintiff attorneys equate error with negligence (and therefore payment) without exception. I counter that while certainly not desired, and as you point out when someone's life is in your hands we strive to "avoid mistakes as much as possible", perfection is not humanly possible. Negligence is, or should be, harmful action beyond the range of customary or expected outcome. In my opinion, this is not the same as error free which is an unattainable standard. Yet, try and convince a lay jury in retrospective analysis a decision, diagnosis, judgment was "wrong" but not negligent.

abstract: The Murphy Oil Corporation bought a stake in an offshore oil project in Australia from the closely held Finder Exploration, its first venture in the country. Murphy, based in El Dorado, Ark., said it had agreed to acquire a 40 percent stake in an exploration permit for an area northwest of Australia and operate the project. Terms were not disclosed. “This acreage acquisition is important as it not only marks our entry into Australia where we see further growth opportunities but complements our existing Southeast Asia position, which is already yielding strong results in Malaysia,” Murphy’s chief executive, Claiborne P. Deming, above, said in a statement.

abstract: British Airways said it would not increase its stake in Iberia Líneas Aéreas de España, dimming prospects that British Airways would be part of a takeover bid for Iberia and increasing the likelihood that it would remain in Spanish hands. By not exercising its right to buy shares being sold by two of Iberia’s Spanish investors, British Airways and the American private equity firm TPG are unlikely to mount a full takeover bid of 3.4 billion euros ($5 billion), as was expected, analysts said. The decision opens the door for Caja Madrid, a large Spanish savings bank, to raise its interests in Iberia. Caja Madrid said last week that it wanted to exercise its own option to buy the Iberia shares held by Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria and Logista, the logistics arm of Altadis, raising its stake in the Spanish carrier to about 24 percent.

abstract: An appearance on television sparks some thinking about career goals, and publicity.

lead_paragraph: My book was featured on the “Today” show yesterday. A one-minute appearance on national television may not sound like a big deal for someone who writes for The New York Times regularly. But it did feel like a big deal. Television is very different from print. And even though I’ve appeared on television several times to talk about my book, it’s still new enough to me that each time I do it, I learn something. The experience reminded me of a few truths about careers — and a few truths about publicity.

headline.main: Lessons From The ‘Today’ Show

lead_paragraph: For a few years starting in the late 1990s, Honeywell was one of those companies that couldn’t stop announcing job cuts. It cut jobs in 1999, even as the rest of the economy was booming. It cut more jobs in 2000, when the stock market bubble began to leak. After the 9/11 attacks, the company, which makes cockpit controls and other high-technology equipment, announced its biggest layoff of all: 15,800 jobs.

lead_paragraph: The United States could shave as much as 28 percent off the amount of greenhouse gases it emits at fairly modest cost and with only small technology innovations, according to a new report.

headline.main: Study Details How U.S. Could Cut 28% of Greenhouse Gases
headline.print_headline: Study Details How U.S. Could Cut 28% of Greenhouse Gases

abstract: On the road for business or commuting from the suburbs, games, gadgets and high-tech devices have caught the attention of businesspeople.

lead_paragraph: For almost every lawyer, accountant, Wall Street executive or deal maker, the briefcase and the BlackBerry can be a lifeline to the office, particularly for those on the road for business or commuting from the suburbs. Executives these days can’t go anywhere without the cellphone or the BlackBerry, but there are other gadgets and high-tech devices that are also catching on — some for work, but many for relaxation.

headline.main: Some Essential Hardware (Even Away From the Street)

abstract: Western officials are concerned that Venezuela, under the leadership of President Hugo Chávez, is becoming increasingly opaque in its finances.
snippet: Western officials are concerned that Venezuela, under the leadership of President Hugo Chávez, is becoming increasingly opaque in its finances.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 29 — As petrodollars stream into oil-producing countries, Western officials have begun to demand greater accountability for how they are spent. Some countries known for corruption, like Nigeria and Azerbaijan, have heeded the call, increasing their financial transparency, or at least paying lip service to it. But Venezuela under the leadership of President Hugo Chávez appears headed in the opposite direction.

headline.main: Chávez Proposals Would Make Finances Opaque
headline.print_headline: Venezuela’s Fateful Choice
